title: Baker Mountain (West Virginia)
text: Baker Mountain is a <a href="mountain">mountain</a> <a href="ridge">ridge</a> in southeastern <a href="Hampshire%20County%2C%20West%20Virginia">Hampshire County</a>, <a href="West%20Virginia">West Virginia</a>. The mountain runs southwest northeast between <a href="Yellow%20Spring%2C%20West%20Virginia">Yellow Spring</a> and the <a href="Hardy%20County%2C%20West%20Virginia">Hardy County</a> line. Baker Mountain is flanked to its east by the <a href="Cacapon%20River">Cacapon River</a> with <a href="West%20Virginia%20Route%20259">West Virginia Route 259</a> running parallel between the two. Its forests were once used as a major source of <a href="timber">timber</a> for the <a href="Baltimore%20and%20Ohio%20Railroad">Baltimore and Ohio Railroad</a>'s rail ties. For this reason, the <a href="Winchester%20and%20Western%20Railroad">Winchester and Western Railroad</a> was constructed through the Capon Valley in the 1920s to haul the timber harvested in the region to <a href="Winchester%2C%20Virginia">Winchester</a>, <a href="Virginia">Virginia</a> for <a href="railroad%20tie">railroad tie</a> production. The communities of <a href="Capon%20Lake%2C%20West%20Virginia">Capon Lake</a> and <a href="Intermont%2C%20West%20Virginia">Intermont</a> lie at the foot of Baker Mountain on the Cacapon.
